<misra_rule>

You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of make_blocking:
```c
static void
make_blocking (MHD_socket fd)
{
#if defined(MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS)
  int flags;

  flags = fcntl (fd, F_GETFL);
  if (-1 == flags)
    abort ();
  if ((flags & ~O_NONBLOCK) != flags)
    if (-1 == fcntl (fd, F_SETFL, flags & ~O_NONBLOCK))
      abort ();
#elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  unsigned long flags = 0;

  if (0 != ioctlsocket (fd, (int) FIONBIO, &flags))
    abort ();
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function make_blocking:
#define MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS 1
...
typedef int MHD_socket
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the entire make_blocking function and the related symbol definitions. I found no uses of compiler language extensions explicitly documented as extensions (for example: __attribute__ / __declspec, __builtin_*, typeof, statement expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, inline asm, label-as-value, zero-length/unnamed bit-fields as compiler extensions, or other vendor-specific keywords). The code uses standard C constructs: preprocessor conditionals (#if defined), typedef int MHD_socket, standard function calls (fcntl, ioctlsocket, abort), integer casts ((int) FIONBIO), and normal bitwise/assignment expressions. The MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS macro and the typedef for MHD_socket are standard preprocessor/type usages, not language extensions. Therefore there are no fragments that need further investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions should not be used).
